poem:
**Daycare Dividends**

In the glow of morning,  
lottery dreams nestled soft,  
a child cradled by a village  
of gentle hands and familiar smiles.  
But overnight, giants came,  
replacing whispers with rules,  
and what was once personal  
turns corporate,  
the new alphabet of care—  
distant, cold, and altogether  
foreign.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "I thought I’d won the daycare lottery. Then our centre was bought out and everything changed | Anonymous When my child was enrolled in my local daycare, I felt as though I’d won the lottery. According to mothers’ groups and parent Facebook forums, it was the early learning centre of the postcode: a small, independently run facility with a reputation for retaining educators, a rare thing in an industry known for burning and churning staff.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
